# Issue 18002: Submonoids and subsemigroup defined by generators

archive/issues_017765.json:
```json

Implement subsemigroups generated by elements of an ambient
semigroups, lazily constructing all the elements and their Cayley
graph relations.

Here is a quick example from the documentation:

```
sage: R = IntegerModRing(12)
sage: R.submonoid([R(3), R(5)], one = R.one())
sage: M.cardinality()
4
```

This builds on and supersedes the old patch
`automatic_monoid-nt.patch` from the Sage-Combinat mercurial queue.


Depends on #17160

CC:  @nthiery @anneschilling days64

Keywords: **monoids, days64**

Branch: **[`a8306e4`](https://github.com/sagemath/sagetrac-mirror/commit/a8306e4da2265d06e6fc20ca3f16989632132fee)**

Reviewer: **Anne Schilling**

Author: **Nicolas M. Thiéry, Aladin Virmaux**

Component: **combinatorics**

_Issue created by migration from https://trac.sagemath.org/ticket/18002_

Thi\u00e9ry.\n+AutomaticMonoid construct (lazily) a monoid from a set of concrete generators living in an ambient monoid.\n+\n+Here is a quick exemple from the documentation:\n+\n+```\n+sage: R = IntegerModRing(12)\n+sage: M = AutomaticMonoid(Family({1: R(3), 2: R(5)}), one = R.one())\n+sage: M.cardinality()\n+4\n+```\n``````\n",

Description changed:
``````diff
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1 +1,11 @@
 Implement the `AutomaticMonoid` class. It is a rewrite of the sage-combinat patch by Nicolas M. Thiéry.
+AutomaticMonoid construct (lazily) a monoid from a set of concrete generators living in an ambient monoid.
+
+Here is a quick exemple from the documentation:
+
+```
+sage: R = IntegerModRing(12)
+sage: M = AutomaticMonoid(Family({1: R(3), 2: R(5)}), one = R.one())
+sage: M.cardinality()
+4
+```
``````

archive/issue_comments_244823.json:
```json
{
    "body": "Description changed:\n``````diff\n--- \n+++ \n@@ -1,11 +1,16 @@\n-Implement the `AutomaticMonoid` class. It is a rewrite of the sage-combinat patch by Nicolas M. Thi\u00e9ry.\n-AutomaticMonoid construct (lazily) a monoid from a set of concrete generators living in an ambient monoid.\n+Implement subsemigroups generated by elements of an ambient\n+semigroups, lazily constructing all the elements and their Cayley\n+graph relations.\n \n Here is a quick exemple from the documentation:\n \n ```\n sage: R = IntegerModRing(12)\n-sage: M = AutomaticMonoid(Family({1: R(3), 2: R(5)}), one = R.one())\n+sage: R.semigroup([R(3), R(5)], one = R.one())\n sage: M.cardinality()\n 4\n ```\n+\n+This builds on and supersedes the old patch\n+``automatic_monoid-nt.patch`` from the Sage-Combinat mercurial queue.\n+\n``````\n",
    "created_at": "2015-03-24T00:20:18Z",
    "formatter": "markdown",
    "issue": "https://github.com/sagemath/sage/issues/18002",
    "type": "issue_comment",
    "url": "https://github.com/sagemath/sage/issues/18002#issuecomment-244823",
    "user": "https://github.com/nthiery"
}
```

Description changed:
``````diff
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,11 +1,16 @@
-Implement the `AutomaticMonoid` class. It is a rewrite of the sage-combinat patch by Nicolas M. Thiéry.
-AutomaticMonoid construct (lazily) a monoid from a set of concrete generators living in an ambient monoid.
+Implement subsemigroups generated by elements of an ambient
+semigroups, lazily constructing all the elements and their Cayley
+graph relations.
 
 Here is a quick exemple from the documentation:
 
 ```
 sage: R = IntegerModRing(12)
-sage: M = AutomaticMonoid(Family({1: R(3), 2: R(5)}), one = R.one())
+sage: R.semigroup([R(3), R(5)], one = R.one())
 sage: M.cardinality()
 4
 ```
+
+This builds on and supersedes the old patch
+``automatic_monoid-nt.patch`` from the Sage-Combinat mercurial queue.
+
``````

<div id="comment:34" align="right">comment:34</div>

Hello,

The commit I just made is stupid: I did not checked I correctly pulled before so it merged pretty well with the last one you made. The second one only corrects some typo in the documentation (mainly I replaced 'monoids' by 'semigroups' to be accurate with the last commits).

The method one() is provided whether the constructed object is a monoid (which is great) or is a semigroup (which is less great). Would not it be better to define this method in the constructor only if the `AutomaticSemigroup` is in `Monoids` ?
There is no real example where the ambient semigroup is actually a semigroup (ie not a Monoid),
may we add and play with the following in the doc ?

```
sage: S = Semigroups().Finite().example()
sage: A = AutomaticSemigroup(Family({1: S('a'), 2: S('ca'), 3: S('bc')}))
sage: A in Semigroups() and A not in Monoids()
True
```

Cheers,
Aladin

<div id="comment:61" align="right">comment:61</div>

Replying to [@nthiery](#comment:60):
> Replying to [@videlec](#comment:58):
> > The example in the description is precisely an example where we want to override the method `.submonoid()` since everything can be computed using `gcd`!

> 
> We are looking for a multiplicative monoid here, not additive. So I don't see from the top of my head how to do it with `gcd`.

Indeed, `gcd` is not enough.

> And I certainly agree that there must be some better way than brute force in such a specific situation. I was just looking for a simple example where one can easily check things by hand.

In the case of `Z/nZ` we know the multiplicative structure! That is indeed a great advantage. I would decompose `Z/nZ = Prod_i (Z/(p_i)^k_i Z`. Then determine the order of the generators in each projection and the (multiplicative) subgroup they generate. And finally glue back.

But I am pretty sure that this was not the situation you had in mind with Aladin when you wrote this ticket ;-)

Vincent
